nit: You've noted before that the flux operation chaining can be unclear and is also the locations where most optimizations happen.
Might be useful to add some comments overall on the topicMessageFlux to help manage the overhead costs in the future.
timeline.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText: sure, I'll add some appropriate comment
replies.author: xin-hedera

timeline.bodyText:
Fix issue that TopicMessage.toResponse does not properly cache the protobuf response

Both the old and new approach properly cache the response. Both the old and the new approach can potentially call consensusTopicResponseBuilder.build() multiple times for the same object. Only difference is that now only one thread will win the transition from null to populated. I don't think that really buys us anything as it's still doing the same amount of work.
We should consider switching to @Getter(lazy=true) as it uses double checked locking and may be more what you're looking for while at the same time being cleaner than using AtomicReference.
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: yes you are right, thought AtomicReference.updateAndGet performs locking.
replies.author: xin-hedera

replies.bodyText: It doesn't lock, it just does a compare and set in a loop

timeline.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.bodyText: This is quite a complicated solution for not much gain in functionality. Why do we even care about letting them consume the buffer after they overflow? There's no recovery logic here so we should just fail fast and let the client retry.
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: it's for the case that the topic TPS is high, the client is slow and can't catch up, since the backpressure buffer is big, letting the client consume the remaining data then terminating it with either the OverflowException or the ClientTimeoutException would end in a rate higher than 500 the client can get by retry.
replies.author: xin-hedera

replies.bodyText: Regardless if we have a buffer timeout or not, the client has to retry right? They can't keep up and the TPS is high. All we're doing is delaying it slightly and give them a little bit higher TPS on the first run but then still slow on the retry anyway. I don't think an extra 2s window provides any value.
replies.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.bodyText: Assuming we keep the timeout logic, have you considered using onBackpressureBuffer(int maxSize, Consumer<?> onOverflow) and use the consumer to trigger the wait before error?
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: yes this simplifies the logic, thanks
replies.author: xin-hedera
